content.description:
Scramble up the massive, easily protected ~5.4 gully for about 50 feet before the more technical climbing starts. Protection gets gradually harder as the chimney constricts. Replace claustrophobia with acrophobia by moving out from the constriction, and start stemming to pull the exposed, runout roof. This is the crux. It's hard to protect this roof and a fall would stuff you in the narrow constriction below. Provided the lack of sunlight seen by this chimney, it was somewhat icy, but surmountable, as of late April, 2020.

There are no bolts at the top of this route, but I slung the obvious boulder at the top, and backed it up with 2 pieces for belay. If you are feeling lucky, there is a single bolt on the right of the top out ledge which could potentially be used for a rappel, otherwise continue up Skyline Arete.

If you know the name of this route, please let me know so I can change it.
content.protection: Full rack of cams. Passive pro didn't seem to fit well for me. If you aren't comfortable with a single bolt rappel, be prepared to finish Skyline Arete.
content.location: Forboding looking chimney immediately right of Crystal Caper.

content.description: Recently given a thorough cleaning and a new anchor (shared with Headline). This is a great line for the aspiring 5.11 leader. Great protection through the finger crux. Another classic Gallatin finger crack.
content.protection: Single rack with small pieces.
content.location: Left of Headline and right of The CDC.

content.description:
Another fine Hall/Swanson route in this area. Climb up over easy ledgey terrain. From here the climbing quickly reaches crux mode, and is sustained most of the way up. Very odd body positions required to make the clips.

Descent:

Rappel route.
content.protection: 8 bolts to chains (shared w/ Electric Horseman).
content.location: About 1/2 way up the Skyline south face.

climbs.name: RRT
climbs.fa: A. Whitmore, Z. Drobnik, J. Apple

content.description: Pillar approximately 75 yards south of Ashes of Stone.  Walk on an independent trail around to the southeast face of pillar. Start at base of short finger crack below 2 bolts.  Moderate trad interspersed with 5. 11+ and .12 face sequences characterizes the climb.  Chain anchors.
content.protection: 90' 6 bolts plus gear to 1 3/4" (3" optional).

climbs.name: Red Beard's Delight
climbs.fa: A. Whitmore, F. Thompson , R. Marks (Summer 2011)

content.description: From right side of low overhanging cave boulder 10' up and left to a stance with a bolt (there are plenty of sticks afoot).  Proceed up and left placing a micro-cam (offset is best)and continue on good holds to right facing corner with 6' horizontal roof. Use crack climbing technique to surmount the roof at 5.10d, 4" cam unit useful.  Mind how your rope runs around the roof.  Then 30' of good jam-crack lead to anchors.
content.protection: One bolt and Micro-cams thru 4".
content.location: Approximately half way up the Skyline south side trail.  South of the middle section of the Skyline southside crags by about a 100 yards.

content.description:
Start on a lower angle, balancey face into some large pocket/dish features. Move through the second pocket/dish (crux), over the bulge, and through some slightly easier, but still thought provoking terrain, to the chains.

Descent:

Rappel route.
content.protection: 8 bolts to chains
content.location: High up on skyline buttress south face. Take the new climbers switchback trail up (a few hundred feet south of the wall; hiking along the wall itself is loose and steep) until near the top, and then cut back left up a trail to the wall. Route starts just right of two dead/leaning trees.

content.description: As the name implies, this climb is somewhat dirty and loose. The movement is fun, however.
content.protection: Single rack to 4". Bring something bigger or sling a marginal knob up high for pro. Otherwise, run it out on easy terrain. No anchors, and not great pro for a TR anchor. Walk off to the climber's right.
content.location: Just to the left of the Hippy Bandana arete, about 15', is a slab leading to a wide, Loose and Dirty crack.

content.description: Climb the thin right-leaning seam using all of your well earned Gally technique.
content.protection: Finagle thin cams and stoppers, or a crash pad or two
content.location: Uphill from Skyline ledge; First crack system right of Crack and a Smile

climbs.name: KnifeHandChop
climbs.fa: A. Whitmore, P. Ramos, Z. Drobnik (October 2014)

content.description: A nice straightforward route.  Take the easy slabs up the start of "Electric Horseman".  Instead of veering right on EH, climb straight up through a 1" crack in an obtuse corner.  Fifteen feet up, the crack closes out and 4 bolts protect a corner capped by two small roofs.
content.protection: Several 1" pieces and 4 draws.  Supplemental gear can protect the beginning slabs.  Two bolt top anchor equipped for cragging.
content.location: Middle section of Skyline's southside base crags, between "Early Bird" and "Electric Horseman".  Hangers are camouflaged. Rappel route from bolted anchor.

content.description: A long moderate climb with a burly, for the grade, lie-back/undercling crux.  Nice rock climbing throughout.  An exposed and excellent 5.9 face protected by 4 bolts finishes the last 30' of the pitch.
content.protection: Crack gear to 2".  Five bolts.  Rappel anchor.  Tie knots in ends of rope, 70m rope.  Its possible for the first to lower to easy 5.5 climbing on good rock 10' above the start.
content.location: Starts to the left of "Alice Springs" going straight up following an open corner system.

content.description:
A good short easy climb if climbing in the upper skyline area/need a bit more after climbing Skyline. Climb the left side of the arete until you can reach around and clip the first bolt. Make an exciting move right around the arete, then straight up to the anchor.

Descent:

Rappel route.
content.protection: 3 bolts to chains.
content.location: High up on skyline buttress south face. Take the new climbers switchback trail up (a few hundred feet south of the wall; hiking along the wall itself is loose and steep) until near the top, and then cut back left up a trail to the wall. Route starts on far right end of wall on the obvious short arete.

climbs.name: Headline
climbs.fa: Trevor Bowman, Pat Kingsbury, Bryan Schmitz 8/17/09

content.description:
This spicy two pitch line parallels Slyline to its left on the south face of Skyline Buttress. It was done ground-up on-sight.

P1 - Start the first pitch in a chossy, pink, right-facing dihedral capped by a small roof about 15' left of the first pitch of Slyline. Climb the corner with a good crack, but suspect rock, to the cruxy hand (or foot) traverse left 7' under the roof. Easier climbing up small corners and blocks on good dark rock leads to the comfy belay ledge beneath the crux chimney pitch on Skyline. (5.10 80')

P2 - Climb the 15' crack up to the belay bolts for the second pitch of Ithica Connection and launch up the blunt green rib which forms the left side of the Skyline Chimney. This is a strenuous and strange pitch up shallow flared cracks with cerebral climbing and sometimes tricky pro. The crux is climbing up the lower rib and wrapping around right toward the chimney into the twin upper crack-grooves. (5.11a 100')

Once around, you can make a big stem across the Skyline Chimney to rest in spots, but you have to leave the stem to enter the upper cracks. If you use the stem to move up the middle stem (instead of just as a rest) it makes it slightly easier; it would be a very proud and burly lead to do this without the stem at all! All three members of the FA party climbed using different methods, with the leader stemming just for rests and gear placement, and one follower stemming up the middle section, and the other following without stemming at all.
content.protection: Cams through #4 new BD, lots of small TCUs and C3s, RPs and small brass nuts, offset TCUS.
content.location: South face of Skyline Buttress. P1 starts 15' left of P1 of Slyline. P2 follows thin cracks up the green rib left of the Skyline Chimney. Rap off Crystal Caper with 2 ropes or continue up Skyline to the top (several short fun steps up to 5.5)

content.description:
A fantastic sport climb high up in the canyon. Pretty sustained climbing, but great rests between harder sections. Very thoughtfully bolted. No clips feel stressed, and the bolts are very close together.

Descent:

Rappel route.
content.protection: 9 bolts to chains.
content.location: High up on skyline buttress south face. Take the new climbers switchback trail up (a few hundred feet south of the wall; hiking along the wall itself is loose and steep) until near the top, and then cut back left up a trail to the wall. Route starts just left of two dead/leaning trees.

content.description: Climb past bolts on big bread loaf pinches. Consistent movement throughout with several .11- cruxes.
content.protection: All bolts.
content.location: Left bolt line below the Hipster Slab.

content.description: Either continue from Layback and be Cool (correct form) or take the 5.9 sneak from the left (12c). Step left from the original bolt to easy crack to the crux at two bolts (If someone finds/excavates decent gear, chop the buggers). Rest and continue up a rather traddy butt flare to the anchors.
content.protection: 3 QD plus single rack to BD #1; double 0.5 and brassies useful
content.location: first crack system left of the anchor bolt of "Layback and Be Cool". Continuing the arch is an old Kalakay project freed my W. Magro "Vernal Equinox" 12+.

content.description: Start the same as for "Basic Goodness", after the initial 20' continue straight up through the overhanging bulge ("Basic Goodness" traverses right here).  Some steep and desperate movement through 3 bolts leads to a great river face prow finish.
content.protection: 5 bolts.
content.location: Located on the large independent rock next to the Skyline descent trail.  Rappel route or walk off.

climbs.name: Eli the Husky Dog
climbs.fa: Zana Drobnik, Pete Redmon, A. Whitmore

content.description:
Climb through the first few bolts of the "Hipster Slab" and then step onto the face 30' left of "Goodbye Babylon".  Follow intricate face moves protected by gear and bolts to a steep upper headwall.  Powerful and exposed moves on good holds lead to a fixed rappel anchor.

NOTE:  The crack that forms the middle 1/3 of the route begins 15' left and above the bolted start.  While appealing, this crack hides two very hollow stacked/wedged blocks each of which weigh a few hundred pounds.  At this time trundling of these is not an option.  The first ascensionists do not recommend climbing on and in no way placing gear in the cracks surrounding these blocks.  The proper start avoids these dangers to the right.
content.protection: Gear to 1.5" and 4 bolts.
content.location: Start at belay ledge for the two routes lookers right, belay bolt.  Rappel route.

content.description:
Scramble up some ledges underneath the bright red streak. Step right over some ledgey terrain and into the left facing, rightward slanting dihedral. A few delicate feet moves are the crux of this route.

Descent:

Rappel.
content.protection: 6 bolts, a few finger sized cams 0.3-0.5, chain anchors (shared w/ Sesame).
content.location: About 1/2 way up the Skyline South face. To the left of this route is a large grassy ramp heading up and left.

content.description: Start in the beginning crack of "Goodbye Babylon", 5.11c/d, probably feels like 5.12 for people under 5'10".  Continue climbing through the rightwards traversing crack at 5.11.  Fantastic moves with good gear lead through the crack.  Roll out of the crack towards its termination and climb 25' of 5.10- bolt protected face.
content.protection: Small to medium nuts and cams to 1", with one 3" cam.  3 bolts up high lead to a bolted rappel station.
content.location: High up the hillside on the south side of Skyline.  Start 30' high on the steep ramp referenced on page 163 of the Dockins guide. Belay bolt.

content.description:
Start in the short crack to the right of the dark streak. Move a tad left, then continue up and right following the obvious quartz vein past massive crystal jugs. Finish over a chockstone to chains. Route ends on same massive ledge at top of 2nd pitch of Skyline. Small runout in the middle, and the pro can be slightly tricky in places, but the climbing is fairly easy. Fun and airy in places!

Descent:

TWO ROPE rappel, or finish upper pitches of Skyline and walk off right.
content.protection:
Gear from 0.1-3". Offset cams/stoppers and slings are useful. There are a few fixed stoppers along the way (as of 2013). Chain anchors.

Note: You need TWO ROPES to rappel this route, or finish the upper pitches of Skyline and walk off.
content.location: Southwest corner of Skyline Buttress. You will start almost directly below the 2nd pitch chimney of Skyline.

climbs.name: Crack'n a Smile
climbs.fa: Tom Kalakay and Aaron Hjelt, Fall 2001

content.description: Start underclinging right off the ground.  Clip 3 bolts and tiptoe over to the smile, where a few more moves put you in a pod with a fixed pin.  Continue up the fun, right leaning lieback crack past one more bolt and some gear before stepping over left to a large ledge.  Chain anchor.
content.protection: 4 bolts, one pin, a .75 and some other finger sized gear for the top.
content.location: First route on the south side of Skyline's main face.  Route starts on a left trending undercling flake.  First bolt is just above head height.

climbs.name: Goodbye Babylon
climbs.fa: A. Whitmore, S. Hoffman, Z. Drobnik (March 2015)

content.description: Start 30' high on the steep ramp referenced on page 163 of the Dockins guide.  Belay bolt for safety.  Hard 5.11 crack/fall-away layback moves off the gun protected by a good nut placement.  At 20' gain a stance and a bolt out left.  Thirty feet of 5.11+ with 4 bolts followed by a moderate corner with two bolts leading to 40' of steep 5.10 face climbing on good gear.  One bolt leads to a nice exit sequence and a fixed anchor.
content.protection: Seven bolts and gear to 1".   A 2" cam is useful for safely leading into upper portion.
content.location: Southside Skyline.

climbs.name: The CDC
climbs.fa: Aaron Hjelt, Tom Kalakay, Robyn Ragins, August 2020

content.description: A short and sweet thug fest through the roof on the left side of the face. Runout at the top but one bolt keeps you off the ground.
content.protection: A few small pieces and quickdraws are all you need. The start is tricky to protect. The roof pro is bomber but specific. A blue DMM Dragonfly was used by the FA.
content.location: The left most line of the face, and of the Skyline proper. Anchors can be reached from the 1st pitch of the Skyline.

content.description:
Start 20' right of "Sesame" (furthest east of first cluster of Hall/Swanson sport routes on south side of Skyline)

Five red/black hangers sit above a perched belay ledge. Two 5.12 cruxes off the belay lead to 70'

of 5.10' trad with a sneaky .11 crux.  Sweet right facing corner finish.  Two bolt rappel anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts. Rack from RPs to 2", heavy on mid-sizes.
content.location: Southside of Skyline, middle zone. A 70m rope is optimal.

content.description: River face of pillar located 75 yards south of the middle of Skyline Buttresse's south face.  Done on sight ground up in loose conditions.  From the amount of loose rock below crux there is no way this was climbed previously.  Cleaned after FA.  Fun climbing with true crux pulling into hanging corner 40' up.  Be glad you didn't do the FA. Gear belay on top and walk off south.
content.protection: Stoppers to 2" cams.   Plenty of runners.
content.location: River face of "Red Beard's Delight" pillar.   It's a walk-off.

content.description: Right leaning hanging corner and bolts. Funky movements...Is it a corner, a slab, a roof? So confused
content.protection: Bolts
content.location: Right route below the Hipster Slab

climbs.name: Alice Springs
climbs.fa: A. Whitmore, Z. Drobnik, J. Griffin

content.description: Rambling face climbing on good rock throughout the climb.  The first half is protected by bolts along with a couple pieces of gear.  A distinct 5.11 crux sequence on bolts awaits in the middle.  Fun climbing protected by a 2" cam to small fingers gear and a bolt rounds out the climb.
content.protection: Eight bolts plus a light selection of gear from small fingers to 2".
content.location: On the ground next to a mature lodgepole pine, just to the east of the steep ramp referenced on page 163 of the Dockins guide.  It is currently the next route downhill and west of Hall & Swanson's "Ulu".   Rappel route.

content.description: This route starts on "Crack and a Smile" for the first 2 or 3 bolts and then traverses left into the obvious flair with fingers in the back.
content.protection: purple tcu through #3 camalot, quickdraws, rappel from the "Crack and a Smile" anchors.
